title: Neptune's Triumph for the Return of Albion
sr_entries:
Mar 20, 1640: Entered to (Andrew?) Cooke (1) and Richard Sergier: "four Masques vizt ... Neptunes triumphes. ... by Ben: Iohnson".
Sep 17, 1658: Entered to Thomas Walkley: "fifteene Masques at Court and else where. ... salvo jure cujuscunque."
Nov 20, 1658: Transferred from Thomas Walkley to Humphrey Moseley: "15. Masques at Crt. & else where."
additional_notes: The masque was prepared for a performance on Jan 6, 1624, which was first postponed and eventually abandoned before being revised into The Fortunate Isles; the title page date follows the legal reckoning.
transcript_title: NEPTVNES TRIVMPH for the returne of ALBION, celebrated in a Masque
transcript_performance: at the Court on the Twelfth night 1623.
transcript_latin: Omnis & ad reducem iam litat ara Deum. Mart. lib.VIII. Epig.XIV.
transcript_modern_spelling: Neptune's triumph for the return of Albion celebrated in a masque at the court on the twelfth night 1623 Omnis et ad reducem iam litat ara Deum Mart lib. Viii Epig xiv

title: The Bondman (The Noble Bondman)
sr_entries:
Mar 12, 1624: Entered to John Harrison (4) and Edward Blackmore: "A play called the Bondman by Phill: Messenger".
Apr 28, 1660: Transferred by Martha Harrison, widow and executrix, and John, son of John Harrison (4), to William Lee (3): "Salvo jure cujuscunque. vizt' ... The Bondman a Play. halfe."
transcript_title: THE BOND-MAN: AN ANTIENT STORIE.
transcript_performance: As it hath been often Acted with good allowance, at the Cock-pit in Drury-lane: by the most Excellent Princesse, the Lady ELIZABETH her Seruants.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Edw: Allde, for Iohn Harison and Edward Blackmore, and are to be sold at the great South dore of Pauls. 1624.

transcript_modern_spelling: The bondman an ancient story as it hath been often acted with good allowance at the cockpit in Drury lane by the most excellent princess the lady Elizabeth her servants by Philip Massinger London printed by Edw. title: Monuments of Honor
illustration_on_tp_or_frontis: Woodcut of the Merchant Taylors' arms
transcript_title: Monuments of Honor. Deriued from remarkable Antiquity, ... Directed in their most affectionate Loue, at the Confirmation of their right Worthy Brother IOHN GORE in the High Office of His Maiesties Liuetenant ouer this His Royall Chamber. Expressing in a Magnificent Tryumph, all the Pageants, Chariots of Glory, Temples of Honor, besides a specious and goodly Sea Tryumph, as well particularly to the Honor of the City, as generally to the Glory of this our Kingdome.
transcript_author: Invented and Written by Iohn Webster Merchant-Taylor.
transcript_performance: and Celebrated in the Honorable City of London, at the sole Munificent charge and expences of the Right Worthy and Worshipfull Fraternity, of the Eminent MERCHANT-TAYLORS.
transcript_latin: -------Non norunt hæc monumenta mori.
transcript_imprint: Printed at London by Nicholas Okes. 1624.

transcript_modern_spelling: Monuments of honor derived from remarkable antiquity and celebrated in the honorable city of London at the sole munificent charge and expenses of the right worthy and worshipful fraternity of the eminent merchant tailors Directed in their most affectionate love at the confirmation of their right worthy brother John Gore in the High office of his majesty's lieutenant over this his royal chamber expressing in a magnificent triumph all the pageants chariots of glory temples of honor besides a specious and goodly sea triumph as well particularly to the honor of the city as generally to the glory of this our kingdom invented and written by John Webster Merchant Tailor Non norunt haec monumenta mori printed at London by Nicholas Okes 1624

title: A Game at Chess
variant_description: There are two issues of this edition. In 412b(i), the preliminaries contain verses in which the "Picture" is "plainly explained" [A1r] and an engraved title page [A2r]. In 412b(ii), the original half-sheet A was replaced by a cancel, which contains the "Prologue" [A1v] and the same explanatory verses [A2r]. See also Greg
sr_entries: Mar 15, 1655: Transferred from Martha Harrison, the widow of John Harrison (4), to John Stafford (1) and William Gilbertson: "The Game att Chesse." [It is very unlikely that this entry refers to this play.]
additional_notes: For the printer of this edition, see Gary Taylor, "A Game At Chess: General Textual Introduction," in Thomas Middleton and Early Modern Textual Culture, 718-19.
transcript_title: A GAME AT CHESSE. ... [in single column] A Game at Chesse is here displayde, | Betweene the Blacke and White-House made, | Wherein Crowne-thirsting Policy, | For the Blacke-House (by Falacy) | To the White-Knight, check, often giues, | And to some straites, him thereby driues; | The Fat-Blacke-Bishop help's also. | With faithlesse heart to giue the blow: | Yet (maugre all their craft) at length, | The White Knight, with wit-wondrous strength; | And circumspectiue Prudency, | Giues Check-mate by Discouery | To the Black Knight; and so at last | The game (thus) won, the Black-House cast | Into the Bagge, and therein shut, | Finde all their plumes and Cockes-combes cut. | Plaine-dealing (thus) by wisedomes guide, | Defeats the cheats of Craft and Pride.
transcript_performance: As it was Acted nine Dayes together at the GLOBE on the Bank-side.
transcript_imprint: Printed. 1625.
transcript_modern_spelling: A game at chess as it was acted nine days together at the globe on the bankside a game at chess is here displayed between the black and white house made wherein crown-thirsting policy for the black house by fallacy to the white knight check often gives and to some straits him thereby drives the fat black bishop helps also with faithless heart to give the blow yet maugre all their craft at length the white knight with wit-wondrous strength and circumspective prudency gives checkmate by discovery to the black knight and so at last the game thus won the black house cast into the bag and therein shut find all their plumes and coxcombs cut plain dealing thus by wisdom's guide defeats the cheats of craft and pride

additional_notes: For the printers of this edition, which was printed in London and not in Leiden, see Gary Taylor, "A Game At Chess: General Textual Introduction," in Thomas Middleton and Early Modern Textual Culture, 715-16.

title: London's Tempe, or The Field of Happiness

transcript_title: Londons Tempe, OR, The Feild of Happines. In which Feild are planted seuerall Trees of Magnificence, State and Bewty, to Celebrate the Solemnity of the Right Honorable Iames Campebell, At his Inauguration into the Honorable Office of Prætorship, or Maioralty of London, ... All the particular Inuentions, for the Pageants, Showes of Triumph, both by Water and land being here fully set downe,
transcript_performance: on Thursday the 29 of October, 1629. ... At the sole Cost, and liberall Charges of the Right worshipfull Society of Ironmongers.

transcript_dedication: "The Epistle" to: James Cambell, Lord Mayor; from: Thomas Dekker [A2r]

title: Albovine, King of the Lombards
sr_entries:
July 27, 1639: Ordered that John Benson have leave to print an impression of 1500 of the tragedy of Albovine by Davenant, the copy never entered and therefore in the disposal of the Court: "Mr Benson desired leaue of the Cort. to print an Imprssion of the play called The Tragedy of Albouine made by Mr Davenant wch was printed in Anno 1629. & neuer entred & therefore in the disposall of this Cort. Vpon Consideracion thereof It was ordered that the said Mr Benson should haue leaue to print an Imprssion of 1500. paying to the Poore of this Company xls." (Court Book C, fol. 166b).
May 3, 1651: Transferred from John Marriot to Richard Marriot: "Salvo Iurie cujuscunque; (vizt:). ... Albovine the play."
Mar 7, 1653: Transferred from Richard Marriot to Humphrey Moseley: "a Copie or booke called The Tragedie of Albouine King of the Lombards. Written by Sr. Wm. Dauenant."
additional_notes: There is no evidence that this play was ever acted, but Davenant may have written it with the intention that it would eventually be performed by a professional playing company.
transcript_title: THE TRAGEDY OF ALBOVINE, KING OF THE LOMBARDS:
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed for R. M. and are to bee sold in Saint Dunstanes Church-yard. 1629.
transcript_dedication: Epistle to: Robert Carr, Earl of Somerset; from: William Davenant [A2r]
transcript_commendatory_verses: 8: by "Hen: Blount"; "Ed: Hyde"; "Rich: Clerk"; "Rob: Ellice"; "Will: Habington"; "Rog: Lorte"; "Tho: Ellice"; "H: Howard" [A2v]
transcript_modern_spelling: The tragedy of Albovine king of the Lombards by Wm Davenant London Printed for R.M. and are to be sold in Saint Dunstan's churchyard 1629
imprintlocation: W.9 (Fleet St. - St. Dunstan's Church / Clifford's Inn)

title: A Chaste Maid in Cheapside
sr_entries:
Apr 8, 1630: Entered to Francis Constable: "A play called The Chast Mayd [of Chepeside added]".
Feb 17, 1648: Transferred from the administrator and administratrixes of Alice Constable decd., the widow of Francis Constable, to Richard Thrale: "Saluo iure cuiusque. ... The Chast Maide of Cheapside a play."
additional_notes: Thomas Middleton and Early Modern Textual Culture dates the first production to Spring 1613; Annals dates it to 1613 [Mar-Aug(?)].
transcript_title: A CHAST MAYD JN CHEAPE-SIDE. A Pleasnt conceited Comedy
transcript_performance: As it hath beene often acted at the Swan on the Banke-side, by the Lady ELIZABETH her Seruants.
transcript_imprint: neuer before printed. ... LONDON, Printed for Francis Constable dwelling at the signe of the Crane in Pauls Church-yard. 1630.
transcript_modern_spelling: A chaste maid in cheapside a pleasant conceited comedy never before printed as it hath been often acted at the swan on the bankside by the lady Elizabeth her servants by Thomas Middleton Gent London printed for Francis constable dwelling at the sign of the crane in Paul's Churchyard 1630

title: Pathomachia, or The Battle of Affections (Love's Loadstone)
sr_entries: Apr 16, 1630: Entered to Francis Constable: "A play Called The Battell of The affections or Loves. Loadstone".
transcript_title: PATHOMACHIA: OR, THE BATTELL OF AFFECTIONS. SHADOWED BY A FAIGNED SIEDGE OF THE CITIE PATHOPOLIS.
transcript_author: Written some yeeres since, and now first published  by a Friend of the deceassed A<small>VTHOR</small>.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Thomas and Richard Coats, for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his Shop in Pauls Church-yard at the Signe of the Crane. 1630.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatorie" to: Henry Carey, 1st Earl of Dover; from: Francis Constable [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: Pathomachia or the battle of affections shadowed by a feigned siege of the city Pathopolis written some years since and now first published by a friend of the deceased author London printed by Thomas and Richard cotes for Francis Constable and are to be sold at his shop in Paul's Churchyard at the sign of the crane 1630

title: 2 The Honest Whore (2 The Converted Courtesan)
sr_entries:
Apr 29, 1608: Entered to Thomas Man (2): "A booke called the second parte of the conuerted Courtisan or honest Whore [no sum]".
Jun 29, 1630: Entered to Nathaniel Butter: "The second part of the Honest Hoore by Th. Dekker".
May 21, 1639: Transferred from Nathaniel Butter to Miles Flesher: "saluo iure cuiuscunque ... The second part of the honest whore."
transcript_title: THE SECOND PART OF THE HONEST WHORE, WITH THE HVMORS  of the Patient Man, the Impatient Wife: the Honest Whore, perswaded by strong  Arguments to turne Curtizan againe: her braue refuting those Arguments. And  lastly, the Comicall Passages of an Italian Bridewell, where the Scæne ends.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Elizabeth All-de, for Nathaniel Butter. An. Dom. 1630.
transcript_modern_spelling: The second part of the honest whore with the humors of the patient man the impatient wife the honest whore persuaded by strong arguments to turn courtesan again her brave refuting those arguments and lastly the comical passages of an Italian bridewell where the scene ends written by Thomas Dekker London printed by Elizabeth Allde for Nathaniel Butter An. Dom 1630

title: The Picture
variant_description: There are two groups of variant states in this edition, one affecting the title page and the outer sheet I. The title page exists in two states, with slight differences in spelling and formatting: Greg 436a(*1) calls the play "A TRAGÆCOMÆDJE"; Greg 436a(†1) calls it "A TRAGECOMEDIE." For sheet I, the typography of Greg 436a(*2) resembles that of neighboring sheets; in Greg 436a(†2), the type of the RT is smaller, and roman capitals frequently appear in italic speakers’ names. The title page and sheet I variants occur independently of each other and thus, in individual copies, can be found mixed together in different combinations. See also Greg

title: Love's Triumph Through Callipolis

Nov 20, 1658: Transferred from Thomas Walkley to Humphrey Moseley: "15. Masques at Crt. & else where."

title: The Spanish Bawd (Calisto and Meliboea)
variant_description: There are three issues of this edition: the imprint for Greg 439a(i*) lists Mabbe as bookseller, while Greg 439a(i†) lists Allot as bookseller and gives the location of his bookshop. Copies of Greg 439a(i†) were also issued unchanged as the second part of a collection with The Rogue in 1634 [Greg 439a(ii)]. See also Greg
sr_entries: Feb 27, 1630: Entered to Ralph Mab: "A play Called The Spannish Bawde."
transcript_title: THE SPANISH BAWD, REPRESENTED JN CELESTINA: OR, The Tragicke-Comedy of CALISTO and MELIBEA. Wherein is contained, besides the pleasantnesse and sweetenesse of the stile, many Philosophicall Sentences, and profitable Instructions necessary for the younger sort: Shewing the deceits and subtilties housed in the bosomes of false seruants, and Cunny-catching Bawds.
transcript_imprint: LONDON Printed by J. B. And are to be sold by RALPH MABBE. 1631.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatory" to: Thomas Richardson (judge); from: "Don diego Peude-ser" (James Mabbe) [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The Spanish bawd represented in Celestina or the tragicomedy of Calisto and Meliboea wherein is contained besides the pleasantness and sweetness of the style many philosophical sentences and profitable instructions necessary for the younger sort showing the deceits and subtleties housed in the bosoms of false servants and coney catching bawds London printed by J.B. and are to be sold by Ralph Mab 1631

title: The Spanish Bawd (Calisto and Meliboea)
variant_description: There are three issues of this edition: the imprint for Greg 439a(i*) lists Mabbe as bookseller, while Greg 439a(i†) lists Allot as bookseller and gives the location of his bookshop. Copies of Greg 439a(i†) were also issued unchanged as the second part of a collection with The Rogue in 1634 [Greg 439a(ii)]. See also Greg
sr_entries: Feb 27, 1630: Entered to Ralph Mab: "A play Called The Spannish Bawde."
transcript_title: THE SPANISH BAWD, REPRESENTED JN CELESTINA: OR, The Tragicke-Comedy of CALISTO and MELIBEA. transcript_imprint: LONDON Printed by J. B. And are to be sold by ROBERT ALLOT at the Signe of the Beare in Pauls Church-yard. 1631.

transcript_title: THE NEW INNE. OR, The light Heart. A COMOEDY.

title: Caesar and Pompey (The Wars of Caesar and Pompey)
variant_description: There are three issues of this edition. The first issue, dated 1631, exists in two states: Greg 444a(i*) advertises "CAESAR AND POMPEY: A Roman Tragedy, declaring their Warres" and lists "George Chapman" as author; Greg 444a(i†) advertises "THE WARRES OF POMPEY and CAESAR" and lists "G. C." as author. The second issue, Greg 444a(ii), dated 1652, advertises the book as the second edition; it contains the same play title and author attribution as Greg 444a(i*). The third issue, Greg 444a(iii), dated 1653, does not advertise an edition number but does claim the play was printed "By the true Copie"; it contains the same play title and author attribution as Greg 444a(i*). See also Greg
sr_entries: May 18, 1631: Entered to Thomas Harper: "a Playe called Cæsar & Pompey by Geo: Chapman".
transcript_title: CAESAR AND POMPEY: A Roman Tragedy, declaring their Warres. Out of whose euents is euicted this Proposition. Only a iust man is a freeman.
transcript_imprint: LONDON: Printed by THOMAS HARPER, and are to be sold by Godfrey Emondson, and Thomas Alchorne. M. DC. XXXI.
transcript_dedication: Epistle to: Lionel Cranfield, 1st Earl of Middlesex; from: George Chapman [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: Caesar and Pompey a roman tragedy declaring their wars out of whose events is evicted this proposition only a just man is a free man by George Chapman London printed by Thomas Harper and are to be sold by Godfrey Emerson and Thomas Alchorn MDCXXXI

title: Albion's Triumph
variant_description: Sheet C exists in two states: Greg 453a(*) does not contain an explicit with Townshend’s name on C4v, while in Greg 453a(†), Townshend’s name was added on C4v, and the catchword on C3v was changed. Corrections to the text in the inner form also caused a change in the catchword on C1v. The inner and outer forms of sheet C are not always in the same state in individual copies. See also Greg
additional_notes: The masque was performed on Jan 8, 1632, so the title page dates follow the legal reckoning.

title: Tempe Restored
additional_notes: The masque was performed on Feb 14, 1632, so the title page dates follows the legal reckoning. The end of the text states that the verses for the masque were "written by" Aurelian Townshend, and the subject, allegory, descriptions, and apparatus of the scenes "invented by Inigo Jones, Surveyor of his Maiesties worke" [C3v].

title: The Devil Is an Ass
total_editions: 1 folio in collection, 1 folio (bibliographically independent and in collection)
sr_entries:
Sep 17, 1658: Entered to Thomas Walkley: "The Devill is an Asse. salvo jure cujuscunque."
Nov 20, 1658: Transferred from Thomas Walkley to Humphrey Moseley: "The Devill is an Asse."
additional_notes: Greg writes, "This edition was evidently printed to take the place" of the first edition of the play printed for the second volume of Jonson's Works, but he adds, "it is also clear from advertisements ... that copies were sold separately (although none are recorded as now occurring in that state) and it is therefore here treated as an independent edition" (Bibliography, 2:605-6). There is another issue of this playbook from 1669 [Greg 457b(ii)], which is not included in DEEP.
transcript_title: THE DIVELL IS AN ASSE. A COMEDIE
transcript_performance: ACTED IN THE YEARE, 1616. BY HIS MAJESTIES SERVANTS.
transcript_latin: HOR. de ART. POET. Fucta voluptatis Causa, sint proxima veris.
transcript_imprint: Imprinted at London,  1641.
transcript_modern_spelling: The devil is an ass a comedy acted in the year 1616 by his majesty's servants the author Ben Jonson Hor de art poet ficta voluptatis causa sint proxima veris Imprinted at London 1641

title: The Courageous Turk, or Amurath the First
sr_entries:
Sep 7, 1631: Entered to Richard Meighen: "a booke called the Play of Amarath the Turke."
Nov 7, 1646: Transferred from Mercy Meighen, the widow of Richard Meighen, to herself and George Bedell: "Amurath the Turke. a play."
transcript_title: THE COVRAGIOVS TVRKE, OR, AMVRATH the First. A Tragedie.
transcript_author: Written by THOMAS GOFFE Master of Arts, and Student of Christ-Church in OXFORD,
transcript_performance: and Acted by the Students of the same House.
transcript_imprint: LONDON Printed by B. A<small>LSOP</small>, and T. F<small>AWCET</small>, for R<small>ICHARD</small> M<small>EIGHEN</small>. 1632.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatory" to: Walter Tichborne (brother of Richard Tichborne, 2nd Baronet); from: Richard Meighen [A2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The courageous Turk or Amurath the first a tragedy written by Thomas Goffe master of arts and student of Christ Church in Oxford and acted by the students of the same house London printed by B. Alsop and T. Fawcet for Richard Meighen 1632

title: The Emperor of the East
sr_entries: Nov 19, 1631: Entered to John Waterson: "a Play booke called the Emperor of the East".
transcript_title: THE EMPEROVR OF THE EAST. A Tragæ-Comœdie. The Scæne Constantinople.
transcript_performance: As it hath bene diuers times acted, at the Black-friers, and Globe Play-houses, by the Kings Maiesties Seruants.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by THOMAS HARPER, for Iohn Waterson, ANNO 1632.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatorie" to: John Mohun, 1st Baron Mohun; from: Philip Massinger [A2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The emperor of the east a tragicomedy the scene Constantinople as it hath been divers times acted at the Blackfriars and Globe playhouses by the king's majesty's servants written by Philip Massinger London printed by Thomas Harper for John Waterson Anno 1632

title: A New Wonder, A Woman Never Vexed
sr_entries:
Nov 24, 1631: Entered to Francis Constable: "a booke called A new wwonder or a woman neuer vext. (a Comedy) by Wm. Rowley".
Feb 17, 1648: Transferred from the administrator and administratrixes of Alice Constable decd., the widow of Francis Constable, to Richard Thrale: "Saluo iure cuiusque. ... A new Wonder a woman never vext. by Wm. Rowley."
transcript_title: A NEW WONDER, A WOMAN NEVER VEXT. A PLEASANT CONCEITED Comedy:
transcript_author: Written by WILLIAM ROWLEY, one of his Maiesties Servants.
transcript_performance: sundry times Acted:
transcript_imprint: never before printed. ... LONDON, Imprinted by G. P. for Francis Constable, and are to be sold at his shop at the signe of the Crane in Saint Pauls Churchyard. 1632.
transcript_modern_spelling: A new wonder a woman never vexed a pleasant conceited comedy sundry times acted never before printed written by William Rowley one of his majesty's servants London imprinted by G.P. for Francis Constable and are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the crane in Saint Paul's Churchyard 1632

title: Holland's Leaguer
variant_description: Sheet A exists in two states, with slightly different imprints; both are listed under the same Greg number (461a), but they have different STC numbers. STC 17443 lists "Swan-Alley" in imprint and the inner form of the sheet is wrongly imposed; STC 17443.5 lists "Swan-Yard" in imprint and the inner form is correctly imposed. Greg does not note the state with "Swan-Alley." See also the other Greg
sr_entries:
Jan 26, 1632: Entered to John Grove: "a [Comedy interlined above Playbrooke sic deleted] called the Leaguer (the reformacions [to be interlined above cros not being deleted] strictly obserued may be printed not otherwise) expressed by thaforesaid wordes of Sr Hen: Herbert".
Sep 25, 1637: Transferred from John Grove to William Leake (2): "these ffour Playes following (vizt.) ... Hollands Leaguer."
transcript_title: HOLLANDS LEAGVER. AN EXCELLENT COMEDY
transcript_author: Written by S<small>HACKERLEY</small> M<small>ARMYON</small>, Master of Arts.
transcript_performance: AS IT HATH BIN LATELY and often Acted with great applause, by the high and mighty Prince CHARLES his Servants; at the private house in Salisbury Court.
transcript_latin: [in single column] ———Vult hæc sub luce videri, | Iudicis argutum quia non formidat acumen.
transcript_imprint: Printed at London by I. B. for IOHN GROVE, dwelling in Swan-Alley within Newgate. 1632.
transcript_modern_spelling: Holland's Leaguer an excellent comedy as it hath been lately and often acted with great applause by the high and mighty Prince Charles his servants at the private house in Salisbury court written by Shackerley Marmion Master of Arts Vult haec sub luce videri iudicis argutum quia non formidat acumen Printed at London by J.B. for John Grove dwelling in Swan Alley within Newgate 1632

title: Changes, or Love in a Maze
sr_entries: Feb 9, 1632: Entered to William Cooke: "a Comedy called the Changes or Loue in a Maze by m<sup>r</sup> Sherley".
transcript_title: CHANGES: OR, Love in a Maze. A COMEDIE,
transcript_performance: As it was presented at the Private House in Salisbury Court, by the Company of His Majesties Revels.
transcript_latin: [in single column] ——————Deserta per avia dulcis | Raptat Amor.——————
transcript_imprint: LONDON: Printed by G. P. for William Cooke, and are to be sold at his shop neere Furnivals Inne gate in Holborne, 1632.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatory" (in verse) to: Lady Dorothy (Devereux) Shirley (later married name of "Stafford") (literary patron and poet); from: James Shirley [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: Changes or love in a maze a comedy as it was presented at the private house in Salisbury court by the company of his majesty's revels written by James Shirley gent deserta per avia dulcis raptat amor London printed by G.P. for William Cooke and are to be sold at his shop near Furnival's inn gate in Holborn 1632

title: The Northern Lass
sr_entries:
Mar 24, 1632: Entered to Nicholas Vavasour: "a Comedy called the Northerne Lasse by mr Broome".
Jul 9, 1653: Transferred from Mary Vavasour, the widow of Nicholas Vavasour, to Humphrey Moseley: "a booke or Copie called The Northerne Lasse, written by Mr Rich: Broome."
transcript_title: THE NORTHERN LASSE, A COMOEDIE.
transcript_performance: As it hath beene often Acted with good Applause, at the Globe, and Black-Fryers. By his Maiesties Servants.
transcript_latin: Hic totus volo rideat Libellus. Mart.
transcript_imprint: LONDON: Printed by AVG. MATHEWES, and are to be sold by NICHOLAS VAVASOVR, dwelling at the little South dore of St. Pauls Church. 1632. [var.: "VAVASOR"]
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatorie" to: Richard Holford (of Gray's Inn); from: Richard Brome [A2r]
transcript_commendatory_verses: 6: by "Ben. Ionson"; "F. T."; "St. Br."; "Iohn Ford"; "Tho. Dekker"; "F. T." [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The northern lass a comedy as it hath been often acted with good applause at the globe and blackfriars by his majesty's servants written by Richard Brome Hic totus volo rideat Libellus mart London printed by Aug Mathewes and are to be sold by Nicholas Vavasour dwelling at the little south door of St. Paul's church 1632
imprintlocation: A.9 (Paul's Churchyard - Little South Door / Paul's Chain)

title: The Fatal Dowry
other_paratexts: Four songs: "First Song"; "Second Song. A Dialogue"; "Cittizens Song of the Courtier"; "Courtiers Song of the Citizen" [A2r]
sr_entries:
Mar 30, 1632: Entered to Francis Constable: "a Tragedy called the ffatall Dowry."
Feb 17, 1648: Transferred from the administrator and administratrixes of Alice Constable decd., the widow of Francis Constable, to Richard Thrale: "Saluo iure cuiusque. ... The ffatall Dowry."
transcript_title: THE FATALL DOWRY: A TRAGEDY.
transcript_author: Written by P. M. and N. F.
transcript_performance: As it hath beene often Acted at the Priuate House in Blackefryers, by his Maiesties Seruants.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by IOHN NORTON, for FRANCIS CONSTABLE, and are to be sold at his shop at the Crane, in Pauls Church-yard. 1632.
transcript_modern_spelling: The fatal dowry a tragedy as it hath been often acted at the private house in blackfriars by his majesty's servants written by P.M. and N.F. London printed by John Norton for Francis Constable and are to be sold at his shop at the crane in Paul's Churchyard 1632

title: The Rival Friends
sr_entries: Jun 13, 1632: Entered to Humphrey Robinson: "a Comedy called The Rivall ffriends.  Peter Hausten".
additional_notes: The play was performed on Mar 19, 1632, so the date in the performance attribution on the title page follows the legal reckoning.
transcript_title: THE RIVALL FRIENDS. A Comœdie,
transcript_author: by The Authour, P<small>ET</small>. H<small>AVSTED</small> M<sup>r</sup>. in Artes in Queenes Colledge.
transcript_performance: As it was Acted before the King and Queens Maiesties, when out of their princely favour they were pleased to visite their Vniversitie of Cambridge, upon the 19. day of March. 1631. Cryed downe by Boyes, Faction, Envie, and confident Ignorance, approv'd by the judicious, and now exposed to the publique censure,
transcript_latin: Non tanti est ut placeam insanire.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Aug. Matthewes for Humphrey Robinson, at the signe of the three Pidgeons in Pauls Church-yard. 1632.
transcript_dedication: Verses to: "the right Honourable, right Reuerend, right Worshipfull, or whatsoever he be or shall bee whom I hereafter may call Patron"; from: Peter Hausted [A2r]
transcript_to_the_reader: "The Præface to the Reader" signed "Pet. Hausted" [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The rival friends a comedy as it was acted before the King and Queen's majesties when out of their princely favor they were pleased to visit their university of Cambridge upon the 19 day of March 1631 cried down by Boys faction envy and confident ignorance approved by the judicious and now exposed to the public censure by the author pet Hausted Mr. In arts of Queen's college non tanti est ut placeam insanire London printed by Aug Mathewes for Humphrey Robinson at the sign of the three pigeons in Paul's Churchyard 1632

title: Londini Artium et Scientiarum Scaturigo, or London's Fountain of Arts and Sciences
illustration_on_tp_or_frontis: Woodcut of the Haberdashers' arms
transcript_title: Londini Artium & Scentiarum Scaturigo. OR, Londons Fountaine of Arts and Sciences. Exprest in sundry Triumphs, Pageants, and Showes, at the Initiation of the Right Honorable NICHOLAS RAYNTON into the Maiorty of the famous and farre renowned City LONDON.
transcript_performance: All the Charge and Expence of the laborious Proiects both by Water and Land, being the sole vndertaking of the Right Worshipfull Company of the Haberdashers,
transcript_latin: ——— Redeunt Spectacula.———
transcript_imprint: Printed at London by Nicholas Okes. 1632.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatory" to: Nicholas Rainton, Lord Mayor; from: Thomas Heywood [A2r]. "The Epistle" to: Hugh Perry (alderman); and Henry Andrewes (alderman); from: Thomas Heywood [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: Londini artium et scientiarum Scaturigo or London's fountain of arts and sciences expressed in sundry triumphs pageants and shows at the initiation of the right honorable Nicholas Raynton into the mayoralty of the famous and far renowned city London all the charge and expense of the laborious projects both by Water and land being the sole undertaking of the right worshipful company of the Haberdashers written by Thomas Heywood Redeunt spectacula printed at London by Nicholas Okes 1632

title: 1 The Iron Age
variant_description: The title page exists in two states: Greg 467a(i) contains the printer's device 367; Greg 467a(ii) contains a woodcut illustration. See also Greg
sr_entries: Aug 2, 1630: Transferred from Nicholas Okes to John Okes: "The Iron Age." (probably an error for The Brazen Age)

title: 2 The Iron Age
illustration_on_tp_or_frontis: Woodcut on title page of Troy burning with the Trojan Horse inside its gates, with three figures labeled "Sinon", "Thersites", and "Pyrhus"
sr_entries: Aug 2, 1630: Transferred from Nicholas Okes to John Okes: "The Iron Age." (probably an error for The Brazen Age)
transcript_title: THE Second Part of the Iron Age: Which contayneth the death of Penthesilea, Paris, Priam, and Hecuba: The burning of Troy: The deaths of Agamemnon, Menelaus, Clitemnestra, Hellena, Orestes, Egistus, Pillades, King Diomed, Pyrhus, Cethus, Synon, Thersites, &c.
transcript_latin: Aut prodesse solent aut Delectare.
transcript_imprint: Printed at London by Nicholas Okes, 1632.
transcript_explicit: Here ends the whole History of the destruction of Troy. FINIS. [K4v]
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatory" to: Thomas Mainwaring (son of Matthew Mainwaring, author); from: Thomas Heywood [A3r]
transcript_character_list: "Drammatis personæ. New persons not presented in the former part of this History" [A2v]
transcript_modern_spelling: The second part of the Iron Age which containeth the death of Penthesilea Paris Priam and Hecuba the burning of Troy the deaths of Agamemnon Menelaus Clytemnestra Helena Orestes Egisthus pylades King Diomed Pyrrhus Cetus Sinon Thersites etc. written by Thomas Heywood aut prodesse solent aut Delectare printed at London by Nicholas Okes 1632

title: The Jealous Lovers
variant_description: There are two issues of this edition, varying in the imprint: Greg 469a(*) does not list a bookseller; Greg 469a(†) lists Ireland as bookseller. See also Greg
total_editions: 2 quartos, 2 octavos (bibliographically independent and in collection), 1 octavo in collection
sr_entries: Jun 3, 1645: Transferred from Richard Ireland and Roger Daniel to Richard Royston: "a Comedie called the Iealous Lovers. by Tho: Randall w<sup>ch</sup> sd Copie was formerly printed at Cambridge as by a Note vnder their hands apps w<sup>ch</sup> is putt vpon the file".

transcript_author: Written by T<small>HOMAS</small> R<small>ANDOLPH</small>, Master of Arts, and Fellow of the House.

title: The Jealous Lovers
total_editions: 2 quartos, 2 octavos (bibliographically independent and in collection), 1 octavo in collection
sr_entries: Jun 3, 1645: Transferred from Richard Ireland and Roger Daniel to Richard Royston: "a Comedie called the Iealous Lovers. by Tho: Randall w<sup>ch</sup> sd Copie was formerly printed at Cambridge as by a Note vnder their hands apps w<sup>ch</sup> is putt vpon the file".
additional_notes: According to Greg, "This edition appears to have been printed to accompany the Oxford collection of Randolph's Poems &c., with which it is often bound up, but of which it is neither an integral part nor an invariable companion, and the mention of a Cambridge bookseller in the imprint proves the intention of separate issue. Three years later the remaining stock was included as part of the London collection of Randolph's Poems &c., 1643, being replaced when exhausted by a reprint dated 1646 [469d]" (Bibliography, 2:618).

total_editions: 2 quartos, 2 octavos (bibliographically independent and in collection), 1 octavo in collection
sr_entries: Jun 3, 1645: Transferred from Richard Ireland and Roger Daniel to Richard Royston: "a Comedie called the Iealous Lovers. by Tho: Randall w<sup>ch</sup> sd Copie was formerly printed at Cambridge as by a Note vnder their hands apps w<sup>ch</sup> is putt vpon the file".
additional_notes: According to Greg, "This edition was printed for the later issue of" the 1643 Randolph collection "after the stock of [469c] was exhausted" (Bibliography, 2:618). It does not seem to have been intended for separate issue.
transcript_title: THE Jealous Lovers. A COMEDIE
transcript_author: Written by THOMAS RANDOLPH, Master of Arts, and Fellow of the House.

Verses to: Anthony Stafford (author); from: Thomas Randolph [A4v]. Verses to: Richard Lane (barrister); from: Thomas Randolph [A5r]. title: A Match at Midnight

title: The Triumph of Peace
variant_description: The pages of this masque were set in duplicate and each set of sheets gathered together indiscriminately, resulting in copies that are combined first (Greg 488a; STC 22458.5) and second (Greg 488b; STC 22459) editions. The half-sheet a, which was not set in duplicate, exists in two states. In Greg 488a,b(*), the title page identifies Shirley as "of Grayes Inne, Gent." and its Latin motto is printed on a single line; Greg 488a,b(†) identifies Shirley only as "Gent." and its Latin motto is printed on two lines. See also Greg
sr_entries:
Jan 24, 1634: Entered to William Cooke: "The Maske of the four Inns of Cort. wth the Sceane as it is to be prsented before his Maty. at white hall the third of ffebr: next".
Dec 12, 1646: Transferred from William Cooke to Humphrey Moseley: "these two playes or masques vizt. ... The Triumph of peace by Mr Iames Shirley".
additional_notes: The masque was performed on Feb 3, 1634, so the title page dates follow the legal reckoning.  The end of the text states that the "Scene and Ornament" for the masque were made by "Inigo Iones Esquire, Surueyer of his Maiesties workes"; and the "composition of the music" performed by "Mr. William Lawes, and Mr. Simon Ives" [D4v].
transcript_title: THE TRIVMPH OF PEACE. A Masque,
transcript_author: Invented and Written, By James Shirley, of Grayes Inne, Gent.
transcript_performance: presented by the Foure Honourable Houses, OR Jnnes of Court. Before the King and Queenes Majesties, in the Banquetting-house at White Hall, February the third, 1633.
transcript_latin: Primum hunc Arethusa mihi———
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Iohn Norton, for William Cooke, and are to be sold at his Shop, neere Furnivals-Inne-gate, in Holborne. 1633.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle" to: the four Inns of Court; from: James Shirley [a2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The triumph of peace a masque presented by the four honorable houses or Inns of court before the king and queen's majesties in the banqueting house at Whitehall February the third 1633 invented and written by James Shirley of Gray's inn gent Primum hunc arethusa mihi London printed by John Norton for William Cooke and are to be sold at his shop near Furnival's inn gate in Holborn 1633

variant_description: The pages of this masque were set in duplicate and each set of sheets gathered together indiscriminately, resulting in copies that are combined first (Greg 488a; STC 22458.5) and second (Greg 488b; STC 22459) editions. The half-sheet a, which was not set in duplicate, exists in two states. In Greg 488a,b(*), the title page identifies Shirley as "of Grayes Inne, Gent." and its Latin motto is printed on a single line; Greg 488a,b(†) identifies Shirley only as "Gent." and its Latin motto is printed on two lines. See also Greg
sr_entries:
Jan 24, 1634: Entered to William Cooke: "The Maske of the four Inns of Cort. wth the Sceane as it is to be prsented before his Maty. at white hall the third of ffebr: next".
Dec 12, 1646: Transferred from William Cooke to Humphrey Moseley: "these two playes or masques vizt. ... The Triumph of peace by Mr Iames Shirley".
additional_notes: The masque was performed on Feb 3, 1634, so the title page dates follow the legal reckoning.  The end of the text states that the "Scene and Ornament" for the masque were made by "Inigo Iones Esquire, Surueyer of his Maiesties workes"; and the "composition of the music" performed by "Mr. William Lawes, and Mr. Simon Ives" [D4v].
transcript_title: THE TRIVMPH OF PEACE. A Masque,
transcript_author: Invented and Written, By James Shirley, Gent.
transcript_performance: presented by the Foure Honourable Houses, OR Jnnes of Court. Before the King and Queenes Majesties, in the Banquetting-house at White Hall, February the third, 1633.
transcript_latin: [in single column] ———— Primum | Hunc Arethusa mihi. ———

In Greg 488b,a(*), the title page identifies Shirley as "of Grayes Inne, Gent." and its Latin motto is printed on a single line; Greg 488b,a(†) identifies Shirley only as "Gent." and its Latin motto is printed on two lines. sr_entries:
May 16, 1631: Entered to John Jackman: "a Tragedy called The noble Spanish Souldier by Tho: Deckar."
Dec 9, 1633: Entered to Nicholas Vavasour: "a Tragedy called The Noble Spanish soldior written by mr Decker".

transcript_latin: [in single column] ———— Non est, Lex Iustior Vlla, | Quam Nescis Artifices, Arte perire Sua.
transcript_imprint: LONDON: Printed for Nicholas Vavasour, and are to be sold at his shop in the Temple, neere the Church. 1634.

imprintlocation: W.11 (Fleet St. - Inner Temple / Temple Church)

title: Perkin Warbeck
variant_description: Leaf L1 exists in two states, with minor differences: in Greg 491a(*), L1v has two rows of ornaments above the epilogue; in Greg 491a(†), it has three rows. See also Greg

title: The Two Noble Kinsmen
sr_entries:
Apr 8, 1634: Entered to John Waterson: "a TragiComedy called the two noble kinsmen by Io: ffletcher & Wm. Shakespeare".
Oct 31, 1646: Transferred from John Waterson to Humphrey Moseley: "these Playes following (vizt) ... The Noble kinsman ... by Mr fflesher".
transcript_title: THE TWO NOBLE KINSMEN:
transcript_author: Written by the memorable Worthies of their time; { Mr. John Fletcher, and | Mr. William Shakspeare. } Gent.
transcript_performance: Presented at the Blackfriers by the Kings Maiesties servants, with great applause:
transcript_imprint: Printed at London by Tho. Cotes, for Iohn Waterson: and are to be sold at the signe of the Crowne in Pauls Church-yard. 1634.
transcript_modern_spelling: The two noble Kinsmen presented at the blackfriars by the king's majesty's servants with great applause written by the memorable worthies of their time Mr. John Fletcher and Mr. William Shakespeare gent Printed at London by Tho. Cotes for John Waterson and are to be sold at the sign of the crown in Paul's Churchyard 1634

title: A Maidenhead Well Lost
illustration_on_tp_or_frontis: Woodcut on title page in two sections: at left, four men and a fool surround a table on which rests an open box containing a baby, while at right, a man and woman kiss
other_paratexts: The title-page woodcut appears again later in the book [H3r]
sr_entries: Jun 25, 1634: Entered to Nicholas Okes: "a play called A Maidenhead well lost".
transcript_title: A Pleasant Comedy, called A MAYDEN-HEAD WELL LOST.
transcript_performance: As it hath beene publickly Acted at the Cocke-pit in Drury-lane, with much Applause: By her Maiesties Seruants.
transcript_latin: Aut prodesse solent, aut delectare.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Nicholas Okes for Iohn Iackson and Francis Church, and are to be sold at the Kings Armes in Cheape-side. 1634.
transcript_modern_spelling: A pleasant comedy called a maidenhead well lost as it hath been publicly acted at the cockpit in Drury lane with much applause by her majesty's servants written by Thomas Heywood aut prodesse solent aut delectare London printed by Nicholas Okes for John Jackson and Francis Church and are to be sold at the king's arms in Cheapside 1634

title: The Late Lancashire Witches
other_paratexts: "Song. II. Act." [L4r]
sr_entries:
Oct 28, 1634: Entered to Benjamin Fisher: "a Play called The Witches of Lancasheire &c".
Mar 27, 1637: Transferred from Benjamin Fisher to Robert Young (by deed of marriage): "The witches of Lancasheire the play."
Jun 14, 1642: Transferred from Robert Young to Miles Flesher (a half interest): "The witches of Lancasheire the play."
Jul 22, 1644: Transferred from Robert Young decd. to James Young (his part): "(Salvo iure cuiuscunque) ... [his part] of the Witches of Lancasheire. a play."
transcript_title: The late Lancashire WITCHES. A well received Comedy,
transcript_author: WRITTEN, By T<small>HOM</small>.  H<small>EYWOOD</small>, AND R<small>ICHARD</small> B<small>ROOME</small>.
transcript_performance: lately Acted at the Globe on the Banke-side, by the Kings Majesties Actors.
transcript_latin: Aut prodesse solent, aut delectare.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Thomas Harper for Benjamin Fisher, and are to be sold at his Shop at the Signe of the Talbot, without Aldersgate. 1634.
transcript_modern_spelling: The late Lancashire witches a well received comedy lately acted at the globe on the bankside by the king's majesty's actors written by Thom. Heywood and Richard Brome aut prodesse solent aut delectare London printed by Thomas Harper for Benjamin Fisher and are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the Talbot without Aldersgate 1634

title: The Triumphs of Fame and Honor
sr_entries: Oct 14, 1634: Entered to Henry Gosson: “the Booke of the Lord Mayours show for this yeare 1634. By Master. [John] Taylor”
additional_notes: The Stationers’ Register entry for this play is not listed in W.W. Greg, A Bibliography of the English Printed Drama to the Restoration, 4 vols. (London: Bibliographical Society, 1939-59); or in the STC, but it is in Edward Arber, A Transcript of the Registers of the Company of Stationers of London, 1554-1640, 5 vols, (1875-1894; Gloucester: Peter Smith, 1967).
transcript_title: THE TRIVMPHS OF FAME and HONOVR: OR THE NOBLE ACcomplish'd solemnity, full of Cost, Art and state, at the Inauguration and Establishment of the true worthy and right nobly minded ROBERT PARKHVRST, into the Right Honourable office of Lord Maior of LONDON. The particularities of every Invention in all the Pageants, Shewes and Triumphs both by Water and Land, are here following fully set downe,
transcript_performance: being all performed by the Loves, Liberall Costs, and charges of the Right Worshipfull and worthy Brother-hood of the Cloth-workers the 29 of October 1634.
transcript_imprint: Imprinted at London 1634.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle dedicatory" (in verse) to: Robert Parkhurst, Lord Mayor; from: John Taylor (unsigned) [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The triumphs of fame and honor or the noble accomplished solemnity full of cost art and state at the inauguration and establishment of the true worthy and right nobly minded Robert Parkhurst into the right honorable office of lord mayor of London the particularities of every invention in all the pageants shows and triumphs both by water and land are here following fully set down being all performed by the loves liberal costs and charges of the right worshipful and worthy brotherhood of the cloth workers the 29 of October 1634 written by John Taylor Imprinted at London 1634

title: Coelum Britannicum
additional_notes: The masque was performed on Feb 18, 1634, so the date in the performance attribution on the title page follows the legal reckoning.
transcript_title: Cœlum Britanicum. A MASQUE
transcript_performance: AT WHITE-HALL IN THE BANQVETTING-HOVSE, ON SHROVE-TVESDAY-NIGHT, THE 18. of February, 1633.
transcript_latin: [in single column] Non habeo ingenium; Cæsar sed jussit: habebo. | Cur me posse negem, posse quod ille putat?
transcript_imprint: LONDON: Printed for Thomas Walkley, and are to be sold at his Shop neare White-Hall, 1634.
transcript_actor_list: "The Names of the Masquers" [F2r]; "The names of the young Lords and Noblemens Sonnes" [F2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: Coelum Britannicum a masque at Whitehall in the Banqueting house on Shrove Tuesday night the 18 of February 1633 Non habeo ingenium Caesar sed iussit habebo cur me posse negem posse quod ille putat London printed for Thomas Walkley and are to be sold at his shop near Whitehall 1634

title: The Temple of Love
variant_description: The title page exists in two states: in 497a(*), Davenant's name is in smaller type than Jones's, and "Majesties" is spelled out; in 497a(†), Jones's and Davenant's names are in the same size type, and "Ma<sup>ties</sup>" is abbreviated. See also Greg
sr_entries: Mar 6, 1658: Transferred from Thomas Walkley to Humphrey Moseley: "The Temple of Love a Masque at Whitehall on Shrove Tuesday 1634. ... all written by Sr William Davenant."
additional_notes: The masque was performed on Feb 10, 1635, so the title page dates follow the legal reckoning.

title: The Shepherds' Holiday
other_paratexts: "Thrysis. A Pastorall Elegie in the person of Sir Kenelme Digby, on the Death of his Noble Lady, the Lady Venetia Digby" with a Latin "Epigramma" for her tomb subscribed "Obijt 1. Maij, 1633." [H1r]
sr_entries: Jan 19, 1635: Entered to John Benson: "a TragiComedy called the Sheapards holliday by I: Rutter."
transcript_title: THE SHEPHEARDS HOLY-DAY. A PASTORALL TRAGI-COMÆDIE. ... WITH AN ELEGIE ON THE DEATH of the most noble Lady, the Lady VENETIA DIGBY.
transcript_performance: A<small>CTED</small> B<small>EFORE</small> B<small>OTH</small> T<small>HEIR</small> M<small>AIESTIES</small> A<small>T</small> W<small>HITE</small>-H<small>ALL</small>, by the Queenes Servants.
transcript_latin: VIR. Nec erubuit Sylvas habitare Thalia.
transcript_imprint: LONDON: Printed by N. and I. Okes, for Iohn Benson, and are to be sold at his shop in St. Dunstans Church-yard in Fleetstreet. 1635.

transcript_modern_spelling: The shepherds' holiday a pastoral tragicomedy acted before both their majesties at Whitehall by the queen's servants with an elegy on the death of the most noble lady the lady Venetia Digby Vir. title: Londini Sinus Salutis, or London's Harbor of Health and Happiness
illustration_on_tp_or_frontis: [see Other Paratexts]
other_paratexts: Woodcut of the Ironmongers' arms [A2v]
additional_notes: The end of the text states that the workmanship for the pageant was done by "the Two Artists, Iohn, and Mathias Chrismas; Successors to their Father, Mr. Gerald Chrismas, late disceased" [B3v].
transcript_title: Londini Sinus Salutis, OR, LONDONS Harbour of Health, and Happinesse. Epressed in sundry Triumphs, Pageants and Showes; at the Initiation of the Right Honorable, CHRISTOPHER CLETHROWE, Into the Maioralty of the farre Renowned City LONDON.
transcript_performance: All the Charges and Expences of this present Ovation; being the sole undertaking of the Right Worshipfull Company of the Ironmongers. The 29. of October. Anno Salutis. 1635.
transcript_latin: ———Redeunt Spectacula,———
transcript_imprint: Printed at London by Robert Raworth. 1635.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle" to: Christopher Clitherow, Lord Mayor; from: Thomas Heywood [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: Londini Sinus Salutis or London's harbor of health and happiness expressed in sundry triumphs pageants and shows at the initiation of the right honorable Christopher Clitherow into the mayoralty of the far renowned city London all the charges and expenses of this present Ovation being the sole undertaking of the right worshipful company of the ironmongers the 29 of October anno salutis 1635 written by Thomas Heywood redeunt spectacula printed at London by Robert Raworth 1635

title: Adrasta, or The Woman's Spleen and Love's Conquest

title: The Triumphs of the Prince d'Amour
sr_entries:
Feb 19, 1636: Entered to Richard Meighen: "a maske called The Triumphs of the Prince D'amour by W: D:".
Nov 7, 1646: Transferred from Mercy Meighen, the widow of Richard Meighen, to herself and George Bedell: "The Triumphes of Prince Damour. ... by mr Davenant."
additional_notes: The masque was performed on Feb 24, 1636, so the title page dates follow the legal reckoning.  The end of the text states that "The Musick of the Songs and Symphanies were excellent compos'd by M<sup>r</sup>. Henry, and M<sup>r</sup>. William Laws, his Majesties Servants" [C4r].
transcript_title: THE TRIUMPHS OF THE PRINCE D'AMOVR. A Masque
transcript_performance: PRESENTED BY HIS Highnesse at His Pallace in the Middle Temple, the 24<sup>th</sup> of Februarie  1635.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed for Richard Meighen, next to the Middle Temple Gate in Fleetstreet. 1635.
transcript_printed_license: "This Masque may be Printed by priviledge of a most ancient Record in the [Office of the] Roles belonging to [the] Prince D’amour. T. Maunsell. Master of Revels to his Highnes. February [the xixth]. 1635." [var.: without the portions in brackets] [A1v]

additional_notes: The masque was performed on Feb 27, 1636, so the imprint date follows the legal reckoning.

title: Love's Mistress, or The Queen's Masque (Cupid and Psyche, or Cupid's Mistress)
variant_description: The are two settings of the outer form of sheet B, one of which exists in two states. Greg 504a(*) contains "Loues" in the HT and an inverted initial "H" on B1r. In some copies, B1r is mis-signed "A" and the RT reads "Loues" on B2v and B4v; in other copies, the signature was changed to "B" and the RT to "Loves." Greg 504a(†) contains "Loves" in the HT on B1r, and the initial "H" is the right way up. See also Greg
sr_entries: Sep 30, 1635: Entered to John Crouch: "a play called The Queenes Maske or Loues Mistresse by m<sup>r</sup> Haywood".
transcript_title: Loves Maistresse: OR, The Queens  Masque.
transcript_performance: As it was three times presented before their two Excellent MAIESTIES, within the space of eight dayes; In the presence of sundry Forraigne AMBASSADORS. Publikely Acted by the QUEENS Comœdians, At the Phœnix in Drury-lane.
transcript_latin: Aut prodesse solent, aut delectare.———
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Robert Raworth, for Iohn Crowch; and are to bee sold by Iasper Emery, at the signe of the Eagle and Child, In Pauls Church-yard. 1636.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatory" to: Edward Sackville, 4th Earl of Dorset; from: Thomas Heywood [A1r]

title: The Platonic Lovers
sr_entries:
Feb 4, 1636: Entered to Richard Meighen: "a Play called the Platonicke Louers by Wm. Davenant."
Nov 7, 1646: Transferred from Mercy Meighen, the widow of Richard Meighen, to herself and George Bedell: "The Platonick Lovers. ... by mr Davenant."

transcript_author: The Authour W<small>ILLIAM</small> D'<small>AVENANT</small>, Servant to her Majestie.

transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed for Richard Meighen, next to the Middle Temple in Fleetstreet. 1636.

transcript_modern_spelling: The platonic lovers a tragicomedy presented at the private house in the blackfriars by his majesty's servants the author William Davenant servant to her majesty London printed for Richard Meighen next to the middle temple in Fleet Street 1636

transcript_latin: Quod non Dant proceres, Dabit Histrio.

title: The Vow Breaker, or The Fair Maid of Clifton
illustration_on_tp_or_frontis: [see Other Paratexts]
other_paratexts: "The Illustration" (explanatory verses) [A1v]; woodcut of four scenes, with printed dialogue legends [A2r]
transcript_title: THE VOW BREAKER. OR, THE FAIRE MAIDE of Clifton.
transcript_performance: In Notinghamshire as it hath beene diuers times Acted by severall Companies with great applause.
transcript_latin: Virg: Æn: lib: 2. 77. Obstupui, steterantque Comæ, & vox fausibus hæsit.
transcript_imprint: LONDON. Printed by IOHN NORTON and are to be sold by ROGER BALL at the signe of the Golden Anchor in the Strand, neere Temple-Barre, 1636.

Aen lib 2 77 Obstupui steterantque comi et vox fausibus haesit London printed by John Norton and are to be sold by Roger Ball at the sign of the Golden anchor in the strand near temple bar 1636
imprintlocation: X.1 (Strand / Drury Lane - Temple Bar Without)

title: The Presentment of Bushell's Rock
variant_description: There are two issues of this edition, varying in the imprint: Greg 511a(*) does not list a bookseller; Greg 511a(†) lists Allam as bookseller. See also Greg
additional_notes: The end of the text states that the music was "compos'd by Symon Ive" [B2r].
transcript_title: THE SEVERALL SPEECHES AND Songs, at the presentment of M<sup>r</sup> B<small>VSHELLS</small> R<small>OCK</small> TO THE QVEENES Most Excellent Majesty.
transcript_performance: Aug. 23. 1636. HER HIGHNESSE being Gratiously Pleased to Honour the said ROCK, not only with HER ROYALL Presence; BVT COMMANDED THE SAME to be calIed after her owne Princely name HENRIETTA. [var.: "HENRETTA."]
transcript_imprint: OXFORD, Printed by L<small>EONARD</small> L<small>ICHFIELD</small>. M.DC. XXXVI.

title: The Entertainment at Richmond
additional_notes: The description notes that the country and other "rude" dances were made by "Simon Hopper" [A3r], and the music "excellently compos'd by Master Charles Coleman" [D4r].
transcript_title: THE KING AND QVEENES Entertainement at RJCHMOND. AFTER THEIR DEPARTVRE from OXFORD: In a Masque,
transcript_performance: presented by the most Illustrious PRINCE, PRJNCE CHARLES Sept. 12. 1636.
transcript_latin: Naturam imitarì licèt facile nonnullis videatur haud est.
transcript_imprint: OXFORD Printed by L<small>EONARD</small> L<small>ICHFIELD</small>, M. DC. XXXVI.
transcript_dedication: "The Dedication" to: Henrietta Maria, Queen (consort of King Charles I); from: unsigned [A2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The king and queen's entertainment at Richmond after their departure from Oxford in a masque presented by the most illustrious prince Prince Charles Sept 12 1636 Naturam imitari licet facile nonnullis videatur haud est Oxford printed by Leonard Lichfield MDCXXXVI

title: Hannibal and Scipio
other_paratexts: "To the Ghosts of Hannibal and Scipio" (verses) signed "Thomas Nabbes" [A2r]; "The Ghosts of Hanniball and Scipio to the Authour" (verses) subscribed "Hannibal. Scipio" [A3r]
sr_entries: Aug 6, 1636: Entered to Charles Greene: "a Play called the history of Anniball & Scipio. by Tho: Nabbs".
transcript_title: HANNIBAL AND SCIPIO. AN HISTORICALL TRAGEDY.
transcript_performance: Acted in the yeare 1635. by the Queenes Majesties Servants, at their Private house in Drury Lane.
transcript_latin: Arma virosque cano.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Richard Oulton for Charles Greene, and are to be sold at the white Lion in Pauls Church-yard. 1637.
transcript_argument: "The Argument of the first Act" [B1r]; "The argument of the second Act" [C4r]; "The argument of the third Act" [E3v]; "The argument of the fourth Act" [G2v]; "The argument of the last Act" [I2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: Hannibal and Scipio an historical tragedy acted in the year 1635 by the queen's majesty's servants at their private house in Drury Lane the author Thomas nabbes arma virosque cano London printed by Richard Oulton for Charles Greene and are to be sold at the white Lion in Paul's Churchyard 1637

title: Microcosmus
sr_entries: Aug 6, 1636: Entered to Charles Greene: "A morrall Maske by Tho: Nabbs".
transcript_title: Microcosmus. A MORALL MASKE,
transcript_author: and heere Set down according to the intention of the Authour T<small>HOMAS</small> N<small>ABBES</small>.
transcript_performance: PRESENTED WITH generall liking, at the private house in S<small>ALISBURY</small> Court,
transcript_latin: Debent et prodesse, et delectare Poetæ.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by RICHARD OULTON for Charles Greene, and are to be sold at the white Lyon in Pauls Church-yard. 1637.
transcript_dedication: Dedication to: "all truly noble, generous and honest spirits"; from: Thomas Nabbes [A3r]
transcript_modern_spelling: Microcosmus a moral masque presented with general liking at the private house in Salisbury court and here set down according to the intention of the author Thomas Nabbes Debent et prodesse et delectare Poetae London printed by Richard Oulton for Charles Greene and are to be sold at the white Lion in Paul's Churchyard 1637
errata: Note on "The errours escap't in the Presse" [A4v]

title: The Elder Brother
sr_entries:
Mar 24, 1637: Entered to John Waterson and John Benson: "a Comedy called the Elder Brother written by Iohn ffletcher".
Oct 31, 1646: Transferred from John Benson to Humphrey Moseley (half): "these two Playes vizt. The Elder Brother. by mr Flesher. halfe".
Oct 31, 1646: Transferred from John Waterson to Humphrey Moseley (his part): "these Playes following (vizt) The Elder Brother his part ... by Mr fflesher".

transcript_performance: Acted at the Blacke Friers, by his Maiesties Servants.

title: A Shoemaker a Gentleman

title: The Martyred Soldier
variant_description: The dedication exists in two states: in Greg 533a(*), it is signed "I. K."; in Greg 533a(†), it is signed "Io. Kirke." See also Greg
sr_entries: Feb 15, 1638: Entered to John Okes: "a Play called the Martyred Soldiour. [by deleted] wth the life & Death of Purser Clinton by H: Shirley". (Since the character Purser Clinton is not in this play, the second part of the entry may refer to another text; Purser and Clinton are characters in Thomas Heywood and William Rowley's Fortune by Land and Sea.)
additional_notes: On the dating, license, and company attribution of this play, see N. W. Bawcutt, The Control and Censorship of Caroline Drama (Clarendon, 1996), 143-44. STC lists the Marigold bookshop in an unknown location (B) in Paul’s Churchyard. But in The Bookshops in Paul’s Cross Churchyard (London: Bibliographical Society, 1990), Peter W. M. Blayney argues that the Marigold bookshop was probably formerly part of the Brazen Serpent and therefore located in A.3 of Paul’s Churchyard (21-22).
transcript_title: THE MARTYR'D Souldier:
transcript_performance: As it was sundry times Acted with a generall applause at the Private house in Drury lane, and at other publicke Theaters. By the Queenes Majesties servants.
transcript_imprint: LONDON: Printed by I. Okes, and are to be sold by Francis Eglesfield at his house in Pauls Church-yard at the signe of the Mary-gold. 1638.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle Dedicatory" to: Kenelm Digby (natural philosopher and courtier); from: "Io. Kirke" [A2r]
transcript_to_the_reader: "To the Courteous Reader" [A3v]; "To the Reader of this Play now come in Print" (in verse) [K2v]
transcript_modern_spelling: The martyred soldier as it was sundry times acted with a general applause at the private house in Drury lane and at other public theaters By the queen's majesty's servants The author H. Shirley Gent London printed by J. Okes and are to be sold by Francis Eglesfield at his house in Paul's Churchyard at the sign of the Marigold 1638

title: Tottenham Court
variant_description: There are three issues of this edition. Greg 540a(i) contains the original title leaf dated 1638, which lists "Richard Oulton" as printer and Green as publisher. The second issue contains a cancel title leaf dated 1639, which lists "R. Oulton" as printer, no publisher, and a slightly different author attribution; it exists in two states; Greg 540a(ii*) names Queen Henrietta Maria's Men, while Greg 540a(ii†) does not name a playing company. Copies of both Greg 540a(i) and Greg 540a(ii†) were also issued in the 1639 Nabbes collection (STC 18337). See also Greg
sr_entries: Apr 5, 1638: Entered to Charles Greene: "a Play Called Tottenham Court. by Thomas Nabbs."

title: Aglaura
variant_description: There are three issues of this edition, varying in the imprint: Greg 541b(*) lists "T. W." as printer and Moseley as publisher; Greg 541b(†) lists Walkley as publisher and Moseley as bookseller. Copies of both issues were also included in the 1646 Suckling collection (Wing S6126, S6126A, S6126B). See also Greg
total_editions: 1 folio, 2 octavos (bibliographically independent and in collection), 1 octavo in collection
other_paratexts: Special title to alternative ending [E2r]
sr_entries:
Apr 18, 1638: Entered to Thomas Walkley: "a Play called Aglaura by Sr. Io: Sucklin knight."
Feb 22, 1648: Transferred from Thomas Walkley to Humphrey Moseley: "Aglaura a play by Sr Iohn Suckling".
additional_notes: Greg writes that this edition was intended to be included in the 1646 edition of Fragmenta Aurea, but he adds, "The alternative imprints, however, may point to an original intention to issue the play separately, and it came, moreover, from a different press from any other part of the volume. Separate copies are occasionally found, but whether they were issued so is uncertain" (Bibliography, 2:681).
transcript_title: AGLAURA.

title: Porta Pietatis, or The Port or Harbor of Piety
additional_notes: The end of the text states that the workmanship for the pageant was done by "the two Brothers, M<sup>r.</sup> John and Mathias Christmas" "the two succeeding Sonnes of that most ingenious Artist M<sup>r.</sup> Gerard Christmas" [C2v].
transcript_title: Porta pietatis, OR, The Port or Harbour of Piety. Exprest in sundry Triumphes, Pageants, and Showes, at the Initiation of the Right Honourable Sir MAVRICE ABBOT Knight, into the Majoralty of the famous and farre renowned City London.
transcript_performance: All the charge and expence of the laborious Projects both by water and Land, being the sole undertaking of the Right Worshipfull Company of the Drapers.
transcript_latin: ——— ——— Redeunt Spectacula ———
transcript_imprint: Printed at London by I. Okes. 1638.

Okes 1638

title: Cleopatra, Queen of Egypt
variant_description: There are three issues of this edition. Greg 553a(i) contains the original title leaf dated 1639. Greg 553a(ii) contains a cancel title leaf dated 1654, which lists different author and performance attributions, and different stationers. Greg 553a(ii) was also issued as part of the 1654 May collection (Wing M1416). See also Greg
sr_entries:
Oct 26, 1638: Entered to Thomas Walkley: "Two Playes called The tragedy of Cleopatra. ...".
Nov 20, 1658: Transferred from Thomas Walkley to Humphrey Moseley: "The Tragedy of Cleopatra Queen of Ægipt ... by Tho: May Esqr."
additional_notes: Greg writes that separate editions of Cleopatra and Julia Agrippina "were printed in 1639, but since the epistle to Sir Kenelm Digby prefixed to Cleopatra is a joint dedication of the two plays, it is clear that these, though otherwise bibliographically distinct, were intended to be issued together as well as separately" (Bibliography, 3:1092). DEEP lists each of these plays only as a single-play playbook, not as part of a collection.
transcript_title: THE TRAGEDIE OF CLEOPATRA Queen of Ægypt.
transcript_performance: Acted 1626.
transcript_latin: Luc. [in single column] ——— quantùm impulit Argos, | Iliacasque domos facie Spartana nocenti, | Hesperios auxit tantùm Cleopatra furores.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Thomas Harper for Thomas Walkly, and are to be sold at his shop at the flying Horse neer York House. 1639.
transcript_dedication: Epistle to: Kenelm Digby (natural philosopher and courtier); from: Thomas May [A2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The tragedy of Cleopatra Queen of Egypt by T.M. acted in 1626 Luc. Quantum impulit argos iliacasque domos facie spartana nocenti hesperios auxit tantum Cleopatra furores London printed by Thomas Harper for Thomas Walkley and are to be sold at his shop at the flying horse near York house 1639

title: Julia Agrippina, Empress of Rome
variant_description: There are three issues of this edition. Greg 554a(i) contains the original title leaf dated 1639; it exists in two states: STC 17718 contains the status attribution "Esq." while STC 17718a does not (the states do not have separate Greg numbers). Greg 554a(ii) contains a cancel title leaf dated 1654, which lists a different play title, author attribution, and stationers. Greg 554a(ii) was also issued as part of the 1654 May collection (Wing M1416). See also Greg
sr_entries:
Oct 26, 1638: Entered to Thomas Walkley: "Two Playes called ... Iulia Agripina empresse of Rome."
Nov 20, 1658: Transferred from Thomas Walkley to Humphrey Moseley: "Iulia Agripina Empresse of Rome. by Tho: May Esqr."
additional_notes: Greg writes that separate editions of Cleopatra and Julia Agrippina "were printed in 1639, but since the epistle to Sir Kenelm Digby prefixed to Cleopatra is a joint dedication of the two plays, it is clear that these, though otherwise bibliographically distinct, were intended to be issued together as well as separately" (Bibliography, 3:1092). DEEP lists each of these plays only as a single-play playbook, not as part of a collection.
transcript_title: THE TRAGEDY OF JULIA AGRIPPINA; Empresse of Rome.

Oct 26, 1638: Entered to Thomas Walkley: "Two Playes called ... Iulia Agripina empresse of Rome."
Nov 20, 1658: Transferred from Thomas Walkley to Humphrey Moseley: "Iulia Agripina Empresse of Rome. by Tho: May Esqr."
additional_notes: Greg writes, Bibliography, 3:1092: "Separate editions of the two plays [553, 554] were printed in 1639, but since the epistle to Sir Kenelm Digby prefixed to Cleopatra is a joint dedication of the two plays, it is clear that these, though otherwise bibliographically distinct, were intended to be issued together as well as separately." DEEP lists each of these plays only as a single-play playbook, not as part of a collection.

title: The City Match
variant_description: There are two issues of this edition. Greg 568b(i) does not contain a title page, was printed as a quarto with 38 lines per page, and was intended to be part of the 1658 Mayne collection (Wing M1480). Greg 568b(ii) contains a title page dated 1659, was printed as an octavo with 35 lines per page, and was sold as a single-play playbook. The octavo issue was printed from the same setting of type as the quarto, the type being first rearranged and then reimposed; only the two prologues were completely reset. See also Greg
total_editions: 1 folio, 1 edition issued in both quarto (in collection) and octavo (single-play playbook)
additional_notes: The City Match was first performed in private court performances and afterward by the King's Men at the Blackfriars.

St of Ch Ch in Oxon Oxford printed by Henry Hall printer to the university for rich Davis 1659

title: Salmacida Spolia
sr_entries: Mar 6, 1658: Transferred from Thomas Walkley to Humphrey Moseley: "Salmatida Spolia a Masque at Whitehall on Tuesday the 21th. of Ianuary 1639. all written by Sr William Davenant."
additional_notes: The masque was performed on Jan 21, 1640, so the title page dates follow the legal reckoning.  The end of the text states that "The Invention, Ornament, Sceans and Apparitions, with their Descriptions, were made by Inigo Iones, Surveyor Generall of his Majesties Workes. What was spoken or sung, by William Davenant, her Majesties Servant. The Subject was set downe by them both. The Musicke was composed by Lewis Richard, Master of her Majesties Musicke" [D4v].
transcript_title: SALMACIDA SPOLIA. A MASQVE.
transcript_performance: Presented by the King and Queenes Majesties, at White-hall, On Tuesday the 21. day of January 1639.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by T. H. for Thomas Walkley, and are to be sold at his shop at the signe of the flying Horse neere Yorke house. 1639.
transcript_modern_spelling: Salmacida spolia a masque presented by the king and queen's majesties at Whitehall on Tuesday the 21 day of January 1639 London printed by T.H. for Thomas Walkley and are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the flying horse near York house 1639

title: The Coronation
sr_entries: Apr 25, 1639: Entered to Andrew Crooke (1) and William Cooke: "these five playes  vidlt ... The Coronation".
transcript_title: THE CORONATION A COMEDY.
transcript_performance: As it was presented by her Majesties Servants at the private House in Drury Lane.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. and are to be sold at the signe of the Greene Dragon, in Pauls Church-yard. 1640.
transcript_modern_spelling: The coronation a comedy as it was presented by her majesty's servants at the private house in Drury Lane written by John Fletcher Gent London printed by Tho. Cotes for Andrew Crooke and William Cooke and are to be sold at the sign of the green dragon in Paul's Churchyard 1640

title: Love's Cruelty
sr_entries:
Apr 25, 1639: Entered to Andrew Crooke (1) and William Cooke: "these five playes vidlt ... Loues Cruellty".
Nov 29, 1639: Entered to John Williams (1) and Francis Eglesfield: "Two Playes vizt. ... a Tragedy called Loues Crueltie. by Iames Shirley". Entry canceled, with note in margin: "Loues Crueltie is Entred before to mr Crooke".
transcript_title: LOVES CRVELTIE. A TRAGEDY,
transcript_performance: As it was presented by her Majesties Servants, at the private House in Drury Lane.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke. 1640.
transcript_dedication: Epistle to: George Porter (royalist army officer); and Charles Porter (son of Endymion Porter; brother of George); from: "W. A." [A2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: Love's cruelty a tragedy as it was presented by her majesty's servants at the private house in Drury Lane written by James Shirley Gent. London printed by Tho. Cotes for Andrew Crooke 1640

title: The Night Walker, or The Little Thief
first_production_date_display: c.1611(?) [revised by Shirley and re-licensed for stage, May 11, 1633]
sr_entries: Apr 25, 1639: Entered to Andrew Crooke (1) and William Cooke: "these five playes  vidlt Night walters ...".
transcript_title: THE NIGHT-WALKER, OR THE LITTLE THEIFE. A COMEDY,
transcript_performance: As it was presented by her Majesties Servants, at the Private House in Drury Lane.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke, and William Cooke. 1640.
transcript_dedication: Epistle to: William Hudson (Esquire; presumably of Gray's Inn); from: Andrew Crooke [A2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The night walker or the little thief a comedy as it was presented by her majesty's servants at the private house in Drury lane written by John Fletcher gent. London printed by Tho. Cotes for Andrew Crooke and William Cooke 1640

title: The Opportunity
variant_description: There are three issues of this edition, varying in the imprint: Greg 575a(*) is dated 1640, lists Cotes as printer, and names Crooke and Cooke as publishers in London; Greg 575a(†) is undated, lists Cotes as printer, and names Crooke as publisher in London; 575a(§) is dated 1640, lists no printer, and names Crooke as publisher in Dublin. See also Greg
sr_entries: Apr 25, 1639: Entered to Andrew Crooke (1) and William Cooke: "these five playes  vidlt ... Oportunity."

transcript_performance: As it was presented by her Majesties Servants, at the private House in Drury Lane.
transcript_imprint: LONDON. Printed by Thomas Cotes for Andrew Crooke, and Will. Cooke, and are to be sold at the Signe of the Greene Dragon in Pauls Church-yard. 1640.
transcript_dedication: Epistle to: Richard Owen (rear admiral); from: James Shirley [A2r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The opportunity a comedy as it was presented by her majesty's servants at the private house in Drury Lane written by James Shirley London printed by Thomas Cotes for Andrew Crooke and Will Cooke and are to be sold at the sign of the green dragon in Paul's Churchyard 1640

title: The Bride
sr_entries: Jul 8, 1639: Entered to Lawrence Blaiklock: "a play called The Bride by Tho: Nabbs".
transcript_title: THE BRIDE, A COMEDIE.
transcript_performance: Acted in the yeere 1638. at the private house in Drury-lane by their Majesties Servants.
transcript_latin: Ovid. epist Herm. ad Orest. [in single column] —— Nec turpe marito est | Aspera pro charo bella tulisse thoro.
transcript_imprint: LONDON. Printed by R. H. for Laurence Blaikelocke and are to be sold at his shop at the signe of the Sugar-loafe next Temple barre in Fleet-street. 1640.
transcript_dedication: Epistle to: "the Generalty of his Noble friends, Gentlemen of the severall Honorable Houses the Inns of Court"; from: Thomas Nabbes [A3r]
transcript_printed_license: "Imprimatur. Math. Clay. April. 6. 1639." [I4r]
transcript_modern_spelling: The bride a comedy acted in the year 1638 at the private house in Drury Lane by their majesties' servants the author Thomas Nabbes Ovid Epist Herm ad Orest nec turpe marito est aspera pro charo bella tulisse thoro London printed by R.H. for Lawrence Blaiklock and are to be sold at his shop at the sign of the sugarloaf next temple bar in Fleet Street 1640

title: The Humorous Courtier (The Duke)
other_paratexts: "A Catalogue of such things as hath beene published by James Sherley Gent." [A1v]
sr_entries: Jul 29, 1639: Entered to William Cooke: "a play called The humerous Courtier. by Iames Shirley".
transcript_title: THE HVMOROVS COVRTIER. A COMEDY,
transcript_performance: As it hath been presented with good applause at the private house in Drury-Lane.
transcript_imprint: LONDON. Printed by T. C. for William Cooke, and are to be sold by James Becket, in the Inner Temple. 1640.
transcript_modern_spelling: The humorous courtier a comedy as it hath been presented with good applause at the private house in Drury Lane written by James Shirley gent London printed by T.C. for William Cooke and are to be sold by James Becket in the inner temple 1640
imprintlocation: W.11 (Fleet St. - Inner Temple / Temple Church)

title: Messalina, the Roman Empress
illustration_on_tp_or_frontis: On engraved title page, images of "CLAVDIVS CÆSAR", "MESSALINA", and "SILIVS" surrounding the title; engraved portrait on frontispiece, inscribed "Vera, ac viva Effigies Nathanaelis Richards Gen:", signed "TR sculp:" [A1v]
sr_entries: Oct 3, 1639: Entered to Daniel Frere: "The Tragedy of Messalina the Roman Emperesse by N: R".
transcript_title:
[engraved title page; A2r] THE TRAGEDY of MESSALLINA
[letterpress title page; A3r] THE TRAGEDY OF MESSALLINA The Roman Emperesse.
transcript_author:
[engraved title page] by N: RICHARDS.
[letterpress title page] Written by NATHANAEL RICHARDS.
transcript_performance: [letterpress title page] As it hath beene Acted With generall applause  divers times, by the Company of his Majesties Revells.
transcript_latin: [letterpress title page; in single column] Optimus hic & formosissimus idem | Gentis patritiæ rapitur miser extinguendus. | Messallinæ oculis. Iuvenal, Satyr. 10.
transcript_imprint:
[engraved title page] london printed for Dan: Frere. 1640
[letterpress title page] London Printed by Tho. Cotes for Daniel Frere, at the signe of the Red Bull in Little Brittaine. 1640.
transcript_dedication: "The Epistle. Dedicatory" [sic] to: John Carey (2nd Earl of Dover); from: Nathaniel Richards [A4r]
transcript_commendatory_verses: 6: by "Stephen Bradwell"; "Robert Davenport"; "Thoma Combe"; "Jo. Robinson"; "Tho. Iordan"; "Tho. Rawlines" [A6r]
transcript_modern_spelling:
The tragedy of Messalina the roman empress as it hath been acted with general applause divers times by the company of his majesty's revels written by Nathanial Richards Optimus hic et formosissimus idem gentis patritiae rapitur miser extinguendus messallinae oculis juvenal satyr 10 London printed by Tho. Cotes for Daniel Frere at the sign of the red bull in Little Britain 1640

The Tragedy of Messalina by N. Richards London Printed for Dan. Frere 1640

title: Christ's Passion
variant_description: There are three issues of this edition, each of which exists in variant states. Issue 1 contains the original preliminary half-sheet a4, the imprint for which lists Legat as printer. There are two settings of the inner form of sheet A: Greg 579a(i*) contains the readings "Herods" [A1v, line 8] and "conscious of" [A8r, line 15]; Greg 579a(i†) contains "Herods" and "conscious to." Issue 2, Greg 579a(ii*) and Greg 579a(ii†), the original half-sheet a4 was replaced by the cancel sheet a8, which adds commendatory verses [a5r], a list of errata [a8r], and "In the Annotations" [a8r]. This issue contains the same variant states of the inner form of sheet A. Issue 3, the title leaf of the second issue [a3r] was replaced by a cancel title leaf, which lists "I. L." as printer and Leake as bookseller. It contains the same variant states of the inner form of sheet A, and its title page also exists in two states: Greg 579a(iii*1,*2) and Greg 579a(iii†1,*2) list the play as a "TRAGEDIE"; Greg 579a(iii*1,†2) and Greg 579a(iii†1,†2) list the play as a "TRAGEDY." See also Greg
other_paratexts: Note on authorship [E5v]; "Annotations" [E6r]
sr_entries: Oct 9, 1639: Entered to John Legat (2): "a booke called Christs Passion. a Tragedy. w<sup>th</sup>. Annotations by Geo: Sands Esq<sup>r</sup>."
transcript_title: CHRISTS PASSION. A TRAGEDIE. WITH ANNOTATIONS.
transcript_imprint: LONDON, Printed by Iohn Legatt. M. D. C. XL.
transcript_dedication: Epistle to: Charles I, King; from: George Sandys [a3r]
transcript_printed_license: "September 17. 1639. Imprimatur: Tho: Wykes" [a4v]; "September 27. 1639. Imprimatur. Ioannes Hansley" [H6v]
transcript_modern_spelling: Christ's passion a tragedy with annotations London printed by John Legat MDCXL
